Unique DMGs represent all DMGs in InH vs. InC, or SubH vs. SubC subtract the common genes between InH vs. InC and SubH vs. SubC. **b** Venn plot of the common genes of DMGs and DEGs in InH vs. InC and SubH vs. SubC. Functional categories showed the specific genes enriched in InH vs. InC and SubH vs. SubC. **c** A simple sketch of apoptosis. **d** ML and FPKM variations of two genes involved in apoptosis.

Combined with the transcriptional data, 67 (10.65% of DEGs) and 55 (6.88% of DEGs) overlap genes were found in InH vs. InC and SubH vs. SubC, respectively (Fig. [6b](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#Fig6)). The relationship between methylation and expression level of the specific genes in InH vs. InC and SubH vs. SubC (Fig. [S5](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM1)) is displayed as a scatterplot. Many of the genes in the intertidal group showed hypomethylation (77%), and 42% of genes showed downregulated expression. In contrast, genes showing hypermethylation combined with upregulated expression accounted for 62% of the genes in the subtidal group. Taken together, a positive correlation was observed between DNA methylation and gene expression, which is in accordance with the trend at the whole-genome level (Fig. [3a, b](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#Fig3)).

Only two genes were common to both groups. One is a component of the HSP gene (CGI\_10004348), which encodes heat-shock 70-kDa protein 12A (HSPA12A), and showed upregulated expression in the two groups under heat shock. However, the methylation varied: intertidal samples showed a positive relationship with expression, whereas subtidal samples showed the opposite (Fig. [S6](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM1)). To validate the WGBS data, a target area containing eight CpGs (276 bp, scaffold1801:18940–19215) on HSPA12A was selected according to the results shown in Integrative Genomics Viewer (Fig. [S7a](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM1)) to carry out BSP. The bisulfite-conversion rates represented by the percentage of unmethylated lambda DNA were over 99%. As shown in Fig. [S7b](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM1), InC was almost unmethylated within the eight CpGs, while InH exhibited higher methylation levels. Similarly, SubH showed higher methylation levels than SubC. These results indicated that the traditional bisulfite-sequencing results were in good accordance with the WGBS data. The function of the other common gene (CGI\_10002343) was not annotated, and both the expression and methylation level of this gene decreased in the two groups when faced with high temperatures (Fig. [S6](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM1)).

Specific genes in InH vs. InC were found to participate in regulation of the apoptotic process, organism development, protein modification, and ion transport. As for subtidal-specific genes, functional categories were enriched in the oxidation-reduction process, ion homeostasis, signal transduction, and proteolysis (Fig. [6b](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#Fig6)). Details of the relevant genes are listed in Tables [S3](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM2) and [S4](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#MOESM2). Among the genes in InH vs. InC, two were found to participate in the apoptotic process. One (CGI\_10006605) is annotated as a caspase-like protein, the other (CGI\_10013106) is a member of the inhibitor of apoptosis protein (IAP) family (Fig. [6c](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#Fig6)). Caspase activation plays a central role in the execution of apoptosis, but IAP is an inhibitor of apoptosis. CGI\_10006605 showed hypomethylation and upexpression, whereas CGI\_10013106 showed hypermethylation and downexpression (Fig. [6](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#Fig6) d). Both of these changes in expression contributed to apoptosis, which was negatively regulated by DNA methylation.

## Discussion

A growing number of studies have shown that a dynamic environment can lead to changes in epigenetic marks, which may influence phenotypic plasticity, and help explain the mechanisms of rapid adaptation and acclimatization in a future of rapidly changing climate (Metzger and Schulte [2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR35); Putnam et al. [2016](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR43); Zhang et al. [2017a](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR57)). Our previous study revealed the phenotypic divergence between intertidal and subtidal oysters (Li et al. [2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR25)). In this study, divergent methylation patterns were revealed between intertidal and subtidal oysters, and the genes potentially regulated by the methylation were identified. This study dissected the heritable component of environment-induced phenotypic variation.

The methylation landscape of _C. gigas_ was investigated in this research. Approximately 15% of CpGs were identified methylated in this study. This result is in accordance with previous studies in _C. gigas_ using WGBS (Gavery and Roberts [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR13); Olson and Roberts [2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR38)). Compared with other invertebrates, this level is lower than that reported in the sea squirt ( _Halocynthia roretzi_, 29%), but higher than that in sea anemones ( _Nematostella vectensis_, 11%) (Zemach et al. [2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR55)). Heat shock can cause significantly decreased and slightly increased methylation levels in intertidal and subtidal oysters, respectively, indicating that DNA methylation can be induced by acute heat shock. This result is supported by previous studies. For example, high temperature can induce significant global DNA methylation changes in _Didemnum vexillum_ (Hawes et al. [2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR18)), and any change in temperature during development and thermal acclimation in adults can increase DNA methylation levels in _Gasterosteus aculeatus_ (Metzger and Schulte [2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR35)). Consistent with previous research on oysters (Gavery and Roberts [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR13)), this study found that DNA methylation tended to be mainly located in gene bodies, with other genomic regions exhibiting less methylation.

As for the relationship between methylation and expression, we found that highly and intermediately expressed genes exhibited the highest degree of methylation in gene bodies. This observation is in agreement with previous studies in the oyster (Gavery and Roberts [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR13); Olson and Roberts [2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR38)), the honeybee (Lyko et al. [2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR31)), eukaryotes (Zemach et al. [2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR55)), and mammals (Aran et al. [2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR2)), indicating that the association of hypermethylation in gene bodies with higher expression appears to be a general phenomenon. The occurrence of gene body methylation, especially in protein-coding sequences, was found that can cause deleterious amino acid substitutions (Dixon et al. [2016](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR8)); to compensate this risk, it was reported that gene body methylation can be altered by environmental factors, and thus balances the expression of housekeeping and environmentally responsive genes to help acclimatization (Dixon et al. [2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR7)). The divergence of phenotypic plasticity in gene expression in oysters has been investigated in a previous study, in which intertidal oysters showed higher plasticity than subtidal oysters (Li et al. [2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR25)). In accordance with this, our research on DNA methylation showed that intertidal oysters were more plastic, which implied that DNA methylation may mediate adaptive phenotypic plasticity.

Oysters derived from intertidal and subtidal areas showed epigenetic divergence. In this study, genotype showed limited influences on epigenetic differentiation between the two tidal oysters, suggesting that the methylation variation we detected was mainly induced by environment. The results of sample clustering showed that the differentiation of DNA methylation between the two groups was greater than that induced by acute heat shock, which emphasized that the mediating role of DNA methylation was strongly influenced by life history in specific environments. This phenomenon is not unexpected, considering the mechanism of DNA methylation building, which allows the stable reproduction of gene-activity states from a parental generation of cells to the next. The epigenetic modification we detected in the oyster could be a quantitative response, since the environment-induced epigenetic effect depends on the magnitude of the affecting factor, such as long-term life history or acute heat shock (Jaenisch and Bird [2003](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR21)). Previous studies reported that oysters inhabiting intertidal areas are considered more heat-tolerant, whereas individuals living in subtidal areas are more heat-sensitive (Diederich and Pechenik [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR6); Li et al. [2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR25)). In this study, intertidal oysters mainly showed genomic hypomethylation, while subtidal samples displayed hypermethylation, in response to heat shock. Interestingly, a similar reverse methylation pattern was also detected in a study of two genotypes of rapeseed seedlings, which found that more DNA demethylation events occurred in the heat-tolerant genotype, while more methylation events occurred in the heat-sensitive genotype (Gao et al. [2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR12)). The reverse methylation pattern implies that the epigenetic differentiation between the two groups of oysters in this study may result from genetic divergence, which could have resulted from post-settlement mortality when oyster larvae settled onshore, although there is a strong gene flow between intertidal and subtidal oysters at the same geographical location (Sanford and Kelly [2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR45); Schmidt and Rand [2001](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR46)).

The extent of the role of DNA methylation in regulating gene expression may be demonstrated by 10.65% and 6.88% DMGs in DEGs in intertidal and subtidal oysters, respectively. Oysters derived from two tidal areas modulate totally different genes in response to heat shock, as intertidal oysters were engaged in apoptosis and organism development processes, while oxidation-reduction and ion homeostasis processes occurred in subtidal oysters. These results indicated that the two groups of oysters were experiencing varied response status, as found by Li et al. ( [2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR25)), who demonstrated different thermal adaptation in different geographical _C. gigas_ populations. Two affected genes related to promotion of the apoptotic process can contribute to thermal response in the intertidal samples, because studies on corals have demonstrated the involvement of apoptosis in response to rising seawater temperature, and suggested that increasing temperatures can activate caspase-dependent apoptosis in irreparable cells to improve organismal changes of survival (Kvitt et al. [2016](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR23); Pernice et al. [2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR40)). The expression of both genes was negatively correlated with DNA methylation, from which can be inferred that DNA methylation can suppress gene expression by inhibiting the binding of transcription factors to DNA, or by recruiting transcriptional repressor proteins (Moore et al. [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR37)). In support of this observation, a negative correlation between DNA methylation and expression of some homeobox gene orthologs during early oyster development has also been reported (Riviere et al. [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR44)). Overall, apoptotic response may play an important role in intertidal adaptation, and the DNA methylation we detected provides a new underlying mechanism.

Several genes in the HSP family were found in both intertidal and subtidal groups. A previous study reported DNA hypomethylation of the _Biomphalaria glabrata_ HSP 70 region in snails under heat shock (Ittiprasert et al. [2015](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR20)). However, our data showed that both hyper- and hypomethylation occur, combined with both increased and decreased expression. This result may be explained by the different habitats and treatments of the organisms. Remarkably, the gene encoding HSPA12A was the only annotated gene that showed significant methylation and expression variation in both intertidal and subtidal oysters. It has been demonstrated to participate in environmental stress-response processes by regulating gene expression in a variety of organisms, such as mussels, mice, and Japanese black cattle (Han et al. [2003](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR15); Masoudi et al. [2008](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR34); You et al. [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR53); Zhu et al. [2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7852555/#CR59)). However, little is known regarding how DNA methylation works on HSPA12A when under environmental stressors. Hence, our results not only complement the existing literature on the role of epigenetics in this gene in response to thermal stress, but also reveal the different regulatory patterns in two regional oysters.

In this study, heritable epigenetic variation was investigated by using F1 offspring subjected to common garden experiment. The divergence between the intertidal and the subtidal oysters for the multiple traits clearly suggests that the environment affects phenotypic variation, and that this adaptive phenotypic divergence may be mediated by DNA methylation that can be transmitted to the next generation. Although transgenerational environment-induced epigenetic variants have been revealed in this study, it remains unclear to what extent the epigenetic changes can stably persist across generations, and what mechanism underlies this DNA methylation erasure and re-establishment.

## Conclusion

Understanding the mechanisms regulating the capacity of organisms to respond to environmental variation is critical in determining the impacts of environmental change on populations. In this study, we used WGBS combined with RNA-seq to investigate DNA methylation features in oysters derived from different tidal areas. Our data demonstrated that DNA methylation in _C. gigas_ can be induced by environmental changes, and differentiation in methylation was detected between intertidal and subtidal oysters. In addition, the genes potentially regulated by methylation were identified. This study revealed that methylation is a mechanism underlying adaptive phenotypic divergence between the intertidal and subtidal oysters. This will facilitate a better understanding of how epigenetic mechanisms participate in environmental stress responses in marine invertebrates, and provides new avenues for resource conservation and management.

# Epigenetic and Genetic Population Structure is Coupled in a Marine Invertebrate

## Abstract

Delineating the relative influence of genotype and the environment on DNA methylation is
critical for characterizing the spectrum of organism fitness as driven by adaptation and
phenotypic plasticity. In this study, we integrated genomic and DNA methylation data for
two distinct Olympia oyster ( _Ostrea lurida_) populations while controlling
for within-generation environmental influences. In addition to providing the first
characterization of genome-wide DNA methylation patterns in the oyster genus
_Ostrea_, we identified 3,963 differentially methylated loci between
populations. Our results show a clear coupling between genetic and epigenetic patterns of
variation, with 27% of variation in interindividual methylation differences explained by
genotype. Underlying this association are both direct genetic changes in CpGs (CpG-SNPs)
and genetic variation with indirect influence on methylation (mQTLs). When comparing
measures of genetic and epigenetic population divergence at specific genomic regions this
relationship surprisingly breaks down, which has implications for the methods commonly
used to study epigenetic and genetic coupling in marine invertebrates.

**Keywords:** oyster, DNA methylation, single-nucleotide polymorphism, _Ostrea_, environment, epigenetic

* * *

## Significance.

We know that genotype and epigenetic patterns are primarily responsible for phenotype, yet
there is a lack of understanding to what degree the two are linked. Here, we characterized
the degree by which genetic variation and DNA methylation variation are coupled in a marine
invertebrate and identified potential mechanisms, with almost a third of the methylation
variation attributable to genotype. This study provides a framework for future studies in
environmental epigenetics to take genetic variation into account when teasing apart the
drivers of phenotypic variation. By identifying methylation variation that cannot be
attributed to genotype or environmental changes during development, our results also
highlight the need for future research to characterize molecular mechanisms adjacent to
genetic adaptation for producing long-term shifts in phenotype.

## Introduction

It is increasingly evident that epigenetic processes both influence phenotype and interact
with genetic variation. One such epigenetic process is DNA methylation, which commonly
refers to the methylation of a cytosine in a CpG dinucleotide. The role of DNA methylation
is diverse across taxa and varies based on the genomic location. In most vertebrates, DNA
methylation is widespread across the genome and silences transcriptional activity when
present in the promoter regions ( [Zemach et al.\\
2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B133); [Wagner et al. 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B121); [Varriale 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B118)). In contrast many marine
invertebrates have sparsely methylated genomes and the influence of methylation on
transcription is more complex ( [Suzuki and Bird\\
2008](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B112); [Roberts and Gavery 2012](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B93); [de Mendoza et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B22)). In both vertebrates and
invertebrates, the removal and addition of methyl groups can become canalized during the
lifetime of that organism, and if occurring in germ cells has the potential to influence
subsequent generations. This heritability of DNA methylation, as well as taxa-specific
methylation rates and patterns, suggest that methylation differences arose in part due to
evolutionary forces ( [Varriale 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B118)).

While the patterns and functions of CpG methylation differ among vertebrate and
invertebrate taxa, in both systems, methylation is highly variable. The evolutionary source
of this variation is now an area of active research, with the two dominant factors appearing
to be (1) an organism's environmental history (intra- and intergenerational), and (2) its
genotype ( [Jaenisch and Bird 2003](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B49); [Danchin et al. 2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B21); [Lienert et al. 2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B69)). Understanding how the environment and
genotype interact to influence DNA methylation is critical for delineating organism fitness
as driven by phenotypic plasticity and adaptation, particularly in the context of global
climate change. Bivalves, and oysters in particular, are a valuable model for investigating
invertebrate methylation patterns due to their experimental tractability and concordant
development of genomic resources ( [Timmins-Schiffman\\
et al. 2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B115)).

DNA methylation has been shown to vary in response to environmental factors in marine
invertebrates ( [Eirin-Lopez and Putnam 2019](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B27)).
In oysters, differential methylation has been reported in response to ocean acidification
( [Downey-Wall et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B25); [Lim et al. 2021](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B72)), salinity stress ( [Zhang, Li, Kong, et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B135)), air exposure
( [Zhang, Li, Yu, et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B137)), and the
herbicide diuron ( [Akcha et al. 2021](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B2)). Because
there are clear associations between methylation and transcriptional activity ( [Gavery and Roberts 2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B35); [Olson and Roberts 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B84); [Rivière 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B92); [Song et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B108);
[Johnson et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B53)), methylation changes
may contribute to phenotypic plasticity in response to abiotic stressors ( [Gonzalez-Romero et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B37); [Downey-Wall et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B25); [Venkataraman et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B119); [Wang et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B123), [2021](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B124); [Lim et al. 2021](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B72)). Methylation changes triggered
by the environment may themselves be heritable if they occur in gametes, leading to
transgenerational plasticity, a relationship that has been described in sea urchins ( [Strader et al. 2019](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B111), [2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B110)). It is the dynamic characteristics of the methylome that is
fueling a growing body of research associating methylation variation with environmental
exposures, particularly in transgenerational studies ( [Eirin-Lopez and Putnam 2019](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B27)). However, few studies have controlled
for (or described) the relationship between methylotype and genotype in test organisms, but
see ( [Kvist et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B64); [Johnson and Kelly 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B52); [Wang et al. 2021](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B124)), likely because in nonmodel taxa, there is
limited understanding of how the methylome is shaped by the genome.

While efforts to explore the influence of genotype on DNA methylation are limited in marine
invertebrates, studies in taxa with advanced genomic resources have identified associations
between genetic variants and DNA methylation ( [Zhang\\
et al. 2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B134); [Banovich et al. 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B6);
[Taudt et al. 2016](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B114); [Yi 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B132)). In oysters, genes with constitutive
high levels of methylation have less genetic variation within populations ( [Roberts and Gavery 2012](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B93)). Similar results have
been found in the honey bee _Apis mellifera_ and the jewel wasp
( _Nasonia vitripennis_; [Lyko et al.\\
2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B76); [Park et al. 2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B86). One direct
mechanism by which genetic and epigenetic variation can be associated is single-nucleotide
polymorphisms (SNPs) that create or remove CpG loci (CpG-SNPs), and therefore can
immediately affect local methylation status ( [Shoemaker et al. 2010](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B101); [Zhi et al.\\
2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B139)). Alternatively, methylation status itself may change the likelihood of an SNP
from occurring by “shielding” genetic mutations from selection, allowing genetic
differentiation to accumulate ( [Klironomos et al.\\
2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B58)), and by changing rates of homologous recombination ( [Li et al. 2012](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B67)) and copy number variation mutation (discussed in
[Skinner et al. 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B104)). Surprisingly, some
recent studies in oysters have found no relationship between genetic and epigenetic
differentiation among populations or breeding cohorts, resulting in the suggestion that
these two processes are uncoupled ( [Johnson and Kelly\\
2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B52); [Jiang et al. 2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B51); [Wang et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B123)).

Genetic changes that are associated with methylation state but located some distance from
the associated CpG are referred to as methylation quantitative trait loci (mQTLs). In
humans, mQTLs may contribute up to 15–20% of interindividual variation in methylation and up
to 70% of population-level methylation variation ( [Heyn et al. 2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B45); [McClay et al.\\
2015](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B81); [van Dongen et al. 2016](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B117); [Husquin et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B48)). These genetic and
epigenetic variants are often associated with complex traits or environmental differences,
such as immunity or history of tobacco exposure ( [Gao\\
et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B34); [Bonder et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B15);
[McClay et al. 2015](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B81)). Mechanistically, mQTLs
have been proposed to operate in a number of ways. Global methylation patterns can be
influenced by changing the expression or activity of methyltransferases, although mQTLs are
rarely found in these genes. Increasingly, transcription factors and their binding sites
have been implicated with mQTLs, as transcription factor binding can prevent methylation of
nearby CpGs ( [Héberlé and Bardet 2019](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B43)). Under
this model, genetic variants in transcription factor–binding sites can influence local
methylation (local mQTLs), whereas genetic variants that affect the activity of wide-acting
transcription factors can influence methylation at many distant CpGs near binding sites for
that specific transcription factors (distant mQTLs). While these mechanisms have not been
investigated in most nonmodel taxa, the conserved roles of transcription factors across taxa
suggest that they may also play a role in shaping methylation variation in invertebrates and
bivalves ( [Bell et al. 2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B10); [Nitta et al. 2015](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B83)). Functional genomics are
needed to further investigate these relationships to ascertain the mechanisms underlying
genetic and epigenetic relationships in nonmodel taxa.

The Olympia oyster ( _Ostrea lurida_) is an emerging model taxa for
investigating the links between environment, genetic adaptation, and epigenetic plasticity
( [Timmins-Schiffman et al. 2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B115); [White et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B128); [Maynard et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B79); [Silliman 2019](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B102)). Native to estuaries from Baja California to the central coast of
Canada, _O. lurida_ extends over strong environmental clines and mosaics
( [Schoch et al. 2006](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B96); [Chan et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B19)). Significant neutral and
putatively adaptive genetic variation has been detected between populations at both regional
and local scales, which is surprising given the potential for high connectivity during the
planktonic larval phase ( [Silliman 2019](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B102)).
Experimental tests for local adaptation among neighboring sites within San Francisco Bay, CA
( [Maynard et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B79)) and Puget Sound, WA
( [Heare et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B41); [Silliman et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B103)) have found phenotypic
variation at fitness-related traits, such as growth, salinity tolerance, and reproductive
timing. By controlling for environmental variation, these studies suggest a strong heritable
component underlying population differences. Whether this component is due to genetic
variation, inherited epigenetic modifications, or a combination is still unknown.

The objective of the current study was to leverage a new _O. lurida_ draft
genome to investigate the relationship between CpG methylation and genetic variation based
on 2b-RAD SNPs. Oysters from two populations in Puget Sound, WA were raised to maturity for
one generation in common conditions to remove lifetime exposure to environmental variation.
These populations have phenotypic variation in larval and adult size and reproductive timing
( [Heare et al. 2017](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B41); [Silliman et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B103); [Spencer et al. 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B109)), show varied gene expression profiles under
stress ( [Heare et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B42)), and come from
sites with different environmental profiles in dissolved oxygen, temperature, pH, salinity,
and food availability ( [Moore et al. 2008](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B82);
[Banas et al. 2015](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B5); [Khangaonkar et al. 2018](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B56)). While some marine invertebrate studies
have associated overall patterns of epigenetic and genetic differentiation between
populations (e.g., [Johnson and Kelly 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B52), to
our knowledge, this is the first to directly link epigenetic and genetic variability by
identifying and functionally characterizing CpG-SNPs and meth-QTLs.

## Results

### Study Design

Adult Olympia oysters ( _O. lurida_) derived from two separate parent
populations in Puget Sound, Washington were reared in Clam Bay, Washington. The two
parental populations were from Hood Canal and South Sound. Details on broodstock
collection and outplanting are described in [Heare\\
et al. (2017)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B41). Shell length and wet weight were measured immediately prior to
adductor tissue dissection. Biallelic SNPs were genotyped in 114 individuals (57 from each
population) using a reduced-representation 2b-RAD approach ( [Wang et al. 2012](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B125)) by mapping to a draft _O._
_lurida_ genome assembly (GCA\_903981925.1; 159,429 scaffolds; N50 = 12,947).
After filtering for sample coverage (at least three reads in >70% of individuals) and a
minimum overall minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.01, genotype likelihoods were calculated
with the software ANGSD (Analysis of Next Generation Sequencing Data) for 5,269 SNPs and
used for subsequent population genetic analyses ( [Korneliussen et al. 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B61)).

To characterize CpG methylation patterns for the first time in an _Ostrea_
spp., we randomly selected nine genotyped individuals from each population and used
methyl-CpG-binding domain (MBD) bisulfite sequencing (MBD-BS). These 18 samples are
referred to as the MBD18 samples. This reduced-representation approach is efficient for
taxa with sparse methylation patterns, as it enriches for methylated DNA regions while
providing single-base resolution through bisulfite conversion ( [Trigg et al. 2022](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B116)). Reads from all MBD18 samples were
concatenated into one “meta-sample” and aligned to the _O. lurida_ genome
to describe general methylation patterns in the Olympia oyster. Concatenating the MBD-BS
reads increased our power to detect methylated loci that may have had low coverage across
individual samples, and also minimized the influence of C-T SNPs being identified as
unmethylated Cs after bisulfite conversion ( [Liu et\\
al. 2012](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B74)). Out of 2,030,624 CpG loci with at least 5× sequencing coverage in the
“meta-sample,” 1,839,241 (90.6%) were methylated, defined as loci with >50% of reads
remaining cytosines after bisulfite conversion.

For comparative methylation analyses, reads from each MBD18 sample were aligned
separately, and a more conservative set of 252,115 loci were used by filtering for loci
with 5× coverage across at least 7 of the 9 samples within each population, resulting in
median coverage 13 ± 3 ( [supplementary\\
table S1, Supplementary Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online). As MBD-BS enriches for methylated
regions, this conservative filtering approach may exclude regions that were methylated in
one population but largely unmethylated in the other. Therefore, we included an additional
251 CpG loci that were minimally sequenced in one population (≤1 sample) and widely
sequenced in the other population (≥7 samples), and annotated samples with missing data in
the low-sequenced population as unmethylated at 5× coverage. Preliminary analyses were
done with a filter of 10× coverage for comparative methylation analyses, and while the
absolute number of significant CpGs was lower, qualitatively the results were similar
( [supplementary fig. S9, Supplementary\\
Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online).

### Genome Annotation and General Methylation Landscape

The draft genome assembly (Accession # GCA\_903981925.1) is 1.1 Gb in size with a contig
N50 of 7.8 kb. Gene prediction identified 32,210 genes, 170,394 exons, and 163,637 coding
sequences. Additionally, 27,331,887 CpG motifs were identified in the genome assembly.

Transposable element identification determined GC content of the genome to be 36.58%.
Retroelements comprised 6.24% of the genome assembly. Those retroelements consisted of
0.03% small interspersed nuclear elements, 5.69% long interspersed nuclear elements, and
0.53% of long terminal repeat elements. DNA transposons made up 3.13% of genome
assembly.

Of the 27,331,887 CpGs in the _O. lurida_ genome, we found that 1,839,241
were methylated (6.73%) using the concatenated MBD18 reads. Of the 1,839,241 methylated
loci 34.5% were intragenic (14.7% in exons, 19.8% in introns), 4.6% and 4.7% were located
2 kb upstream and downstream of known genes, respectively, and 13.8% were within
transposable elements. 32.3% of the methylated loci were not associated with known regions
(i.e., intergenic beyond 2 kb gene flanking regions; [fig. 1](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F1)). The distribution of methylated loci across genomic features differed
significantly from the distribution of all CpG loci in the _O. lurida_
genome ( _χ_ 2 = 685,890, df = 5, _P_ ∼ 0), and
methylated CpG loci were ∼3.7× more likely to be located within an exon ( [supplementary fig. S2, Supplementary\\
Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online). By not excluding C-T SNPs from this analysis, we may be
underestimating methylation levels in areas with high nucleotide diversity.

### Population Genetic Structure

Population genetic analyses of all 114 individuals found evidence of divergence with gene
flow between the two populations. Principal component analysis (PCA) of 5,269 SNPs
clustered individuals primarily by population of origin along PC1, which represented 4.5%
of the total variation ( [fig. 2](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F2)). South sound
individuals are separated along PC2, which may suggest some intrapopulation genetic
diversity due to drift from stochastic reproductive success ( [Hedgecock and Pudovkin 2011](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B44)). NGSadmix was used to perform an
ADMIXTURE analysis based on genotype likelihoods of 3,724 SNPs, after filtering further
for a minimum overall allele frequency of 0.05 ( [Skotte et al. 2013](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B105)). The most likely number of genetic clusters
( _K_) was determined to be _K_ = 2, with evidence of
admixture between the two sampled populations ( [supplementary fig. S7, Supplementary Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online). Outlier
analyses with BayeScan detected 12 SNPs as potentially under divergent selection ( [Foll and Gaggiotti 2008](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B33)). One of these SNPs was
found in a gene involved in cell mitosis (G2/mitotic-specific cyclin-B) and another was
within 2 kb downstream of a gene involved in protein ubiquitination (SOCS5; [supplementary table S5, Supplementary\\
Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online).

Population genetic differentiation ( _F_ ST) was measured overall
and separately for each SNP and each gene region (± flanking 2 kb; [Reynolds et al. 1983](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B90)). These values were derived from estimates
of the site-frequency spectrum (SFS) in ANGSD, and therefore used 5,882 SNPs that were
filtered as to avoid distorting the allele-frequency spectrum ( [Korneliussen et al. 2014](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B61)). Overall unweighted
_F_ ST between the two populations was 0.0596 (SD = 0.087), and
weighted _F_ ST was 0.0971. Per-SNP
_F_ ST was calculated for 5,882 SNPs, with 1,909 of these SNPs
found across 1,386 genes. Mean _F_ ST for SNPs in genes was
slightly lower than overall _F_ ST with an unweighted
_F_ ST of 0.0586 (SD = 0.084) and weighted
_F_ ST of 0.093. Thirty-eight genes had an
_F_ ST \> 0.3, and were enriched for four biological
processes, including steroid hormone-mediated signaling pathway and three processes
related to autophagy ( [supplementary\\
table S6, Supplementary Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online).

### DNA Methylation Differences Between Populations

Population methylation analyses of the MBD18 individuals found evidence of epigenetic
divergence. PCA, which was performed on a percent methylation matrix (252,366 loci × 18
samples), clustered individuals by population of origin along PC2, which represented 8.5%
of the total variation ( [fig. 3](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3) _[B](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3)_). Logistic regression analysis
identified 3,963 differentially methylated loci (DMLs) between populations (methylation
difference >25% and _Q_-value <0.01, [supplementary fig. S4, Supplementary\\
Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online), 1,915 of which were located within known genes (48.3% of DMLs),
and 1,504 of which were within exons (40.0% of DMLs). An additional 178 and 171 of the
DMLs were found upstream and downstream of genes (within 2 kb; 4.5% and 4.4%,
respectively), and 188 were located within transposable elements (4.7%). There were 500
DMLs that were not found in any known feature (12.6%). 54% of DMLs had higher methylation
levels in SS (2,154 loci), and 46% were higher in HC (1,809; [supplementary fig. S2, Supplementary\\
Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online).

Population divergence of methylation was also assessed at the gene level for gene regions
containing ≥5 informative loci. Of the 6,299 gene regions assessed, 1,447 were
differentially methylated gene regions (DMGs) as determined by binomial generalized linear
models (GLMs). DMGs and gene regions containing DMLs were each enriched for 31 biological
processes, both of which included sarcomere organization (GO:0045214), and metabolic
process (GO:0008152) ( [supplementary\\
table S4, Supplementary Material](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#sup1) online). Mean _P_ ST,
an analog of _F_ ST, was used to measure population divergence in
methylation ( [Johnson and Kelly 2020](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B52)).
_P_ ST and _F_ ST are comparable
metrics of population divergence, as both assess the proportion of variance within a
population to the total variance, and range from 0 to 1 with increasing values indicating
more differentiation. _P_ ST averaged across 14,088 random 10 kb
bins was 0.30 ± SD 0.26.

### Relationship Between Genetic and Epigenetic Variation

To investigate the relationship between genetic and DNA methylation variation, we first
compared pairwise genetic distances between MBD18 samples with pairwise Manhattan distance
based on all filtered methylation data and found a weak, but significant relationship
(Pearson's _R_ = 0.27, _P_ = 0.00077 and Spearman's
_ρ_ = 0.22, _P_ = 0.0069; [fig. 4](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F4) _[A](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F4)_). This correlation was stronger when comparing against Manhattan
distances based on DMLs (Pearson's _R_ = 0.73, _P_ <
2.2E10−16 and Spearman's _ρ_ = 0.70, _P_ <
2.2E10−16; [fig. 4](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F4) _[B](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F4)_). This suggests that the rate of
genetic changes between individuals is correlated to the rate of methylation changes,
especially for CpG sites that diverge between populations. We further compared population
specificity of our data by correlating the first PC scores from SNP data (9.5% of
variation, [fig. 3](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3) _[A](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3)_) with the second PC scores of
methylation data (8.5%, [fig. 3](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3) _[B](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3)_), as these two axes clearly
separated individuals by population. These were strongly correlated (Pearson's
_R_ = −0.83, _P_ = 1.65E10−5 and Spearman's
_ρ_ = −0.86, _P_ < 2.2E10−16; [fig. 3](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3) _[C](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F3)_), suggesting that common underlying mechanisms may be
involved in population divergence at variable genetic and epigenetic sites. However, we
found no significant correlation between _F_ ST and
_P_ ST at 827 random 10 kb genomic bins where we had
overlapping SNP and methylation data ( [fig.\\
5](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-F5)). By not finding a relationship between spatially linked epigenetic and genetic
sites, our results suggest that the strong correlation between genetic and epigenetic
patterns on the individual level is mediated more by distant (i.e.,
_trans_) interactions than local interactions.

#### mQTL Analysis

To determine if genetic variants are associated with loci showing interindividual
methylation variation, we conducted an mQTL analysis using a linear regression model in
the R package MatrixEQTL ( [Shabalin 2012](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B98)).
For this analysis, we used 2,860 SNPs that had a MAF > 0.05 across the MBD18 samples
as the explanatory variable, PC1-3 of SNP genotype data as a covariate to control for
ancestry, and the percent methylation at 232,567 CpG sites as the response variable.
“Local” mQTLs were determined to be SNPs within 50 kb of the CpG and an un-adjusted
_P_-value threshold of 0.01, whereas distant mQTLs were >50 kb from
the CpG or on a different scaffold and had a false discovery rate (FDR) threshold of
0.05. Due to the reduced representation of our two data sets, only 10,320 CpGs (4.4% of
total) and 853 SNPs (29.8%) were within 50 kb and tested for local mQTLs. Therefore, our
discussion of local mQTL results must be interpreted conservatively, as we are likely
missing many local mQTL relationships. Results of the mQTL analysis are summarized in
[table 1](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-T1), with 1,985 SNPs (69.4%)
detected as mQTLs and 7,157 CpGs (3.1%) associated with an mQTL. Due to linkage
disequilibrium (LD) among SNPs as well as our reduced-representation genetic sequencing,
most of these SNPs are unlikely to be the actual causal variant influencing the
methylated site. Therefore, we follow the recommendation of [McClay et al. (2015)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B81) and evaluate the methylated sites
associated with genetic variants, rather than the specific SNPs themselves, as a better
representation of genetic influence on the methylome.

regulator” (3.9%). Some genes containing these distantly controlled CpGs include 7
different RNA-binding motif proteins, 6 RNA polymerase genes, 8 DEAD-box-type helicases,
17 eukaryotic translation initiation factor (eif) genes, and 6 SWI/SNF regulator of
chromatin. While most other enrichment tests presented here were not significant after

Single-nucleotide polymorphisms that create or remove CpGs (CpG-SNPs) may contribute to
individual differences in methylation, and therefore lead to mQTL associations or
correlations between genetic and epigenetic distances. Identifying SNPs directly from
bisulfite-treated DNA sequencing data can be challenging, as bisulfite treatment removes
C-T polymorphisms. For our study, we used an independent sequencing approach (2b-RAD) to
identify potential CpG-SNPs. We identified 651 CpG-SNPs (12.4%) from our full set of
5,269 SNPs through mapping to our draft genome. CpG-SNPs were more likely to be within
350 bp of a methylated CpG than non-CpG-SNPs (40.9% vs. 34.5%, _P_ =
0.00161), when using all CpGs in the genome as the background. This 350 bp window size
represents the maximum length of a library fragment, and therefore is the maximum
distance at which a CpG-SNP could directly affect our measure of methylation. CpG-SNPs
were slightly more likely to be within 350 bp of a DML than non-CpG-SNPs (0.9% vs. 0.4%,
_P_ = 0.04086), suggesting that CpG-SNPs only play a minor role in
creating DMLs. More of the methylated sites with local meth-QTLs had a CpG-SNP compared
with distant mQTLs (12 vs. 8, _P_ = 1.508e−13). Due to the sparse genetic
sequencing of the genome, we are likely missing many CpG-SNPs associated with both local
and distant mQTLs.

We investigated the spatial overlap between population DMLs and CpGs associated with
local mQTLs, and found CpGs with local mQTLs were more likely to overlap with DMLs than
CpGs without an mQTL association (24.1% vs. 15.9%, _P_ = 0.001289). Genes
of particular interest included PRICKLE2 (developmental processes, linked to growth in

2020\]](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B131)), TRIM2 (innate immunity, differential methylation to low pH in
_Magallana hongkongensis_ larvae \[ [Ozato et al. 2008](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B85); [Lim\\
et al. 2021](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B72)\]), eukaryotic translation initiation factor 3 (eif3) (translation
initiation through mRNA recruitment and interactions with methyltransferases, response
to low pH in _Saccostrea glomerata_ \[ [Ertl et al. 2016](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10468963/#evad013-B29); [Wolf\\
